titleStmt.title: "I care about winning some but losing none!"-Attentional mechanism of mutable-hidden zero effect in economic choices

affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences

analytic.title: "I care about winning some but losing none!"-Attentional mechanism of mutable-hidden zero effect in economic choices

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: In risk-related economic choices, designating zero as "winning $0" or "losing $0" asymmetrical shapes subsequent decision preferences-a phenomenon known as the mutable-zero effect. However, little is known about whether mutable-zero effect pertains to risky decision-making and what cognitive mechanisms underlie it. Here, we examine this question by conducting an eye-tracking experiment where participants (N = 110) chose between certain and risky options. Critically, risky options

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In many economic decision-making scenarios, options with a zero outcome (i.e., neither gaining nor losing money) are often overlooked due to their lack of monetary value. Evidence has shown that zero outcomes could, in fact, affect individuals' judgments and decision-making, depending on the framing of each decision problem. For instance, presenting an investment as having "a 50% chance of not making any money" may suggest incompetence, while framing it as "a 50% chance of avoiding losses" can enhance perceptions of trustworthiness. This phenomenon that an option with a zero outcome fares better or worse depending on how the zero outcome is described is referred to as the mutable-zero effect (Bateman et al., 2007;Scholten et al., 2019;Wardley & Alberhasky, 2021).

Theoretically, the mutable-zero effect can initially be accounted for by the Prospect Theory (Kahneman & Miller, 1986;Scholten et al., 2019). That is, zero outcomes are evaluated based on a reference point in gambles. "Losing $0" is perceived as positive because it implies avoiding losses, while "winning $0" is seen as negative because it represents foregone gains. Thus, the zero outcome of gambles framed as "losing $0" are arguably more attractive than those framed as "winning $0." Moreover, due to loss aversion that suggests an asymmetrical utility of gains vs losses (Tversky & Kahneman, 1991), the disappointment of "winning $0" has a stronger impact than the relief of "losing $0," contributing to the mutable-zero effect.

Notably, the impact of zero outcomes can vary in risky decision-making. Although zero outcomes have no monetary value, they differ in two key aspects: framing (whether the zero outcome is perceived as winning nothing or losing nothing) and probability (the likelihood of encountering the zero outcome).

These differences can lead to varying choice behaviors and cognitive impacts on decision-making. For example, research shows that the mutable-zero effect is more pronounced in the gain domain than in the loss domain (Scholten et al., 2019). Additionally, the probability of gaining or losing nothing may also moderate the mutable-zero effect. Specifically, the impact of a zero outcome likely varies with different probability conditions. Since "winning $0" is a treated as a "bad zero", increasing the probability of a winning zero outcome may heighten risk aversion. Conversely, "losing $0" is a "good zero"; so decreasing the probability of a losing zero outcome may boost risk-seeking. Moreover, research has shown that individuals' risk preferences differ across probability levels: individuals are more risk aversive for high-probability gain and low-probability loss scenarios, whereas they are more risk-seeking for low-probability gain and high-probability loss scenarios (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). This suggests that "winning $0" and "losing $0" should exert influence in distinct scenarios and probability contexts. For instance, "losing $0" could be more effective in high-risk aversion scenarios (e.g., a high-probability gain scenario) by indicating that the worst outcome involves losing nothing, thereby reducing unnecessary risk aversion. Understanding these moderated effects has important implications, as the mutable-zero effect can be strategically used to nudge individuals toward better decisions. A deeper understanding of how probability moderates the mutable-zero effect could refine choice architecture, making nudges more effective in guiding behavior. However, previous studies have focused on the mutable-zero effect within only a narrow range of probabilities (Wakker, 2010;Zhang & Maloney, 2012;Scholten et al., 2019), leaving it unclear how probability moderates this effect across a broader spectrum. In this study, we explored a wider range of probabilities and hypothesized that variability in zero outcomes may prompt distinct risky choice preferences across various probability levels.

In addition, existing models explaining the mutable-zero effect are primarily descriptive, with 100 limited formal quantifications of the underlying cognitive computational mechanisms. Economic 101 behavior, shaped by complex cognitive processes, is not fully captured by outcome-focused models, 102 which often overlook the dynamics of decision-making (Chen et al., 2024;Imas et al., 2022;Zhou et 103 al., 2016). In the digital economy era, the vast cognitive process data-such as attention (Fisher, 2021;(Chen et al., 2024;Konovalov & Krajbich, 2020;Stillman et al., 2018)-can be leveraged to investigate these mechanisms. Attention, a finite resource (Kahneman, 1973), is often unevenly distributed across available information during predecisional processing and is closely linked to the formation of preferences (Brandstätter & Körner, 2014;Ghaffari & Fiedler, 2018;Gwinn et al., 2019;Fisher, 2021;Forest et al., 2022;Pärnamets et al., 2015;Roberts et al., 2022;Sui et al., 2020;Zilker & Pachur, 2023). Attention plays an important role in daily decisions, including perceptual (Tavares et al., 2017), memory-based (Weilbächer et al., 2021, intertemporal (Fisher & Rangel, 2021), and consumer choices (Fisher, 2017;Krajbich et al., 2012). More importantly, exploratory studies of the zero effect (i.e., explicitly presenting zero outcomes) have shown that zero outcomes can alter individuals' choice preferences (Magen et al., 2008), and subsequently, researchers have proposed that attention plays a central role in explaining zero effect. In risky choices, zero outcomes can shift focus toward risky options (Zhou et al., 2019). Similarly, in intertemporal choices, explicit-zero framing can shift attention from smaller-sooner (SS) to larger-later (LL) options (Radu et al., 2011;Dang et al., 2021;Read et al., 2017). Altogether, these studies suggest that the presentation of zero outcomes may influence the allocation of attention during the decision-making process, thereby leading to changes in choice preferences. Regarding the mutable-zero effect, attention allocation is also likely a key mechanism influencing decision preferences. For instance, presenting a zero outcome inherently draws attention, and when its framing contrasts with the gamble's domain-such as "losing $0" in a gain domain-its salience increases, making it more likely to capture attention and prompt further consideration by decision-makers. Additionally, because of loss aversion (Tversky & Kahneman, 1991), outcomes framed as losses tend to be more attention-grabbing and emotionally impactful than those framed as gains, making "lose $0" more likely to attract attention than "win $0." Exploring the attentional mechanisms underlying the mutable-zero effect can also enhance nudge design by identifying key attentional drivers and adjusting external cues such as option saliency or labeling to guide decision-makers toward desired outcomes (Lin et al., 2022;Shimojo et al., 2003;Vriens et al., 2020). Therefore, in the present study, we focused on the potential attentional mechanism of the mutable-zero effect with eye-movement data that captured trial-wise attention. We hypothesize that framing zero outcomes as "win $0" or "lose $0" has asymmetrical effects on attention, which in turn drives differences in decision preferences.

Moreover, computational modeling has been increasingly used to formally quantify the relationship between choice and attention by linking between latent computational process and decision-making behavior (Eum et al., 2023;Scheibehenne & Pachur, 2015) and we have developed novel computational models that integrate eye movement and behavioral data to exploring the attentional mechanism of mutable-zero effect (Zhou et al., 2019). Our model was primarily developed based on the framework of the attentional drift-diffusion model (aDDM) (Krajbich et al., 2010(Krajbich et al., , 2012, one of the most widely-applied models for assessing attentional mechanisms. In addition, we integrated Cumulative Prospect Theory (CPT) to determine whether our mutable-zero findings were driven by attentional mechanisms or value computation. The aDDM emphasizes the critical role of imbalanced attention towards options in decision making, proposing that visual attention modulates the evidence accumulation process (Krajbich et al., 2010(Krajbich et al., , 2012. It has been demonstrated to accurately predict gaze patterns and explain the relationship between gaze patterns and choice preferences across various process-tracking studies (Fisher, 2017;Orquin & Loose, 2013;Smith & Krajbich, 2019;Tavares et al., 2017;Zhu, 2022), with two variants: multiplicative and additive aDDMs. The primary distinction between these two models is how attention influences the evidence accumulation process. The multiplicative aDDM suggests that fixation amplifies the value of the more attended option, while the additive aDDM proposes that attention provides a fixed and independent bias toward a choice option (Cavanagh et al., 2014;Smith & Krajbich, 2019;Thomas et al., 2019;Westbrook et al., 2020). We, therefore, sought to test both multiplicative and additive aDDMs for examining the attentional mechanism underlying the mutable-zero effect on economic choices.

In summary, the current study extended the probability levels to a large range to comprehensively test the mutable-zero effect in both the gain and loss domains. More importantly, using eye tracking modeling, we aimed to assess how attention is modulated to guide individuals' choice preferences when zero outcomes are presented. Lastly, we built novel computational models to trace whether the mutable-zero effect was attributed to attentional mechanism (as informed by aDDM) or value computation (as informed by CPT) by synthesizing behavioral readouts and process dynamics.

Theoretically, our research bridges the gap between attention and economic decision-making, providing novel insights into how probability and framing of zero outcomes jointly influence the mutable-zero effect in choices, and uncovers the underlying cognitive computational mechanisms through combined computational modeling and eye-tracking. The latter can also be applied to wider decision-making research. Practically, understanding the mutable-zero effect offers valuable strategies for nudging individuals toward better decisions.

div.head: Participants
div.p: The sample comprised 110 undergraduate students (female = 78, Mage = 20.33, SDage = 1.03) from the research participant pool at a university in Guangdong Province, China. All participants had normal or corrected-to-normal vision and signed consent forms before the study. The sample size was determined based on studies with mutable-zero effect with limited probability ranges in risky decisionmaking (Scholten et al., 2019), where there were approximately 450 observations in each zero-outcome frame. In contrast, our study extended the single probability level question to encompass a full range of probability levels, with probability values collected at 10% intervals. Each participant completed 80 trials, yielding around 5,600 observations in each zero-outcome frame. As a result, we increased the number of observations under each condition by more than 12-fold and enrolled approximately 110 subjects for three zero-outcome frames. This substantial dataset provided ample material for our grouplevel computational modeling analysis of choices, fixations, and response times (Smith & Krajbich, 2019). Each participant was paid ¥15 (Chinese Yuan ¥1 ≈ $0.15) cash for their participation. To incentivize the participants, they were endowed with an additional amount ranging from ¥5 to ¥40, as per their actual performance during the experiment. The study was approved by the local ethics review board.

div.head: Apparatus
div.p: Eye movements were monitored using an EyeLink 1000 Plus eye tracker (SR Research, Canada) with the eye position sampled at 1000 Hz. The displays were presented on a 24-inch LED monitor running at a refresh rate of 114 Hz with a resolution of 1920 × 1080 pixels. A chin rest located 80 cm away from the monitor was used to minimize head motion. When viewed from this distance, the screen was fixed at a visual angle of 28° horizontally and 21° vertically. The eye tracker is calibrated using a 9-point calibration procedure. Drift correction (operated by the experimenter) was performed before each trial. The participants' responses were recorded by logging button presses on a keyboard.

div.head: Design and stimuli
div.p: The study used a 3 (zero-outcome frame: win ¥0 vs. lose ¥0 vs. hidden ¥0) × 2 (task domain: gain vs. loss) mixed factorial design, in which the frame of zero outcome was a between-subject factor (Nwin ¥0 = 37, Nlose ¥0 = 37, Nhidden ¥0 = 36), and the task domain was a within-subject factor. In all conditions, the participants were asked to choose between pairs of certain options (CNY 100 or CNY 120) and risky options (risk probability ranges from 5%−96%) with approximately equivalent expected values (EVs).

Risk probability refers to the probability of the non-zero outcome of risky options. Participants completed a task comprising 100 pairs of risky choices, of which 1/5 were fillers, with 40 experimental trials in the gain domain and 40 experimental trials in the loss domain (see Supplemental Material Table S1 for the items). The order of the two task domains was randomized and counterbalanced.

Each choice was presented vertically (see Fig. 1, top). For simplicity and consistency of format, we used "+" and "−" signs to denote the gain domain and the loss domain, respectively, and an "×" sign (i.e., "nothing") as a placeholder when some option attributes were not available (see also Section 2.4). Additionally, we used the "+ 0" sign to denote "win ¥0" (e.g., 15%, + 0 denotes a 15% chance of winning ¥0; See Fig. 1, top, A and D) and the "− 0" sign to denote "lose ¥0" (e.g., 15%, − 0 denotes a 15% chance of paying ¥0; See Fig. 1, top, B and E). The order of presentation modes was counterbalanced; that is, the risky and certain options were either presented on the left or right and zero outcomes or placeholders and non-zero outcomes were either presented on the top or bottom. The outcome dimension and the probabilistic dimension of the options were either presented on the top or bottom, constituting eight different presentation layouts. Additionally, to ensure that participants could not perceive or identify more than one attribute simultaneously without making sufficient eye movements (Rayner, 2009), any two of the eight attributes (four outcomes and four probabilities) in a single stimulus appeared in the periphery of the visual field (outside the central 5° of the visual field).

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Upon arrival at the laboratory, participants first read the instructions about the experiment and stimuli and then underwent a short quiz to confirm that they fully understood the experiment. Before the experiment, each participant was calibrated to the eye tracker until the eye tracking was satisfactorily accurate. Then, participants completed five practice trials to familiarize themselves with the experiment.
After completing these procedures, the participants began the main experiment.

At the beginning of each trial (see Fig. 1, bottom), a fixation dot was presented at the center of the display. When the fixation on that calibration point was registered, the participants pressed the spacebar to start the presentation of the choice stimulus. Participants indicated their choice by pressing "F" (for the left option) or "J" (for the right option) on the keyboard. After the participant responded-or the choice stimulus had been shown for 20,000 ms, feedback was shown for 1,000-ms and a blank screen was presented for about 500-800 ms (inter-trial interval) before the next trial started. After completing one block (gain-or loss-domain), participants could take a brief break. Participants completed the eyetracker calibration and five practice trials again before starting the second block (loss-or gain domain).
The order of the two domains was randomized and counterbalanced.

div.head: Transparency and Openness
div.p: A preprint was posted on PsyArXiv (https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/nqkpw).

All study materials, data, and analysis scripts are publicly available online (https://osf.io/y354a/). This study was not preregistered. solid rectangles = certain options; blue rectangles = non-zero outcomes; red rectangles = zero outcomes or placeholder.

div.head: Analyses and results
div.p: Overall, 110 participants completed 8,800 choices (80 trials per participants). Of all choices, 31

were excluded based on our exclusion criteria: in two choice trials, the responses were not recorded; in 29 choice trials, the dwell time was quicker or slower than three standard deviations of the mean for participants or choices "timed out" (response time exceeded 20,000ms), resulting in 8,769 (99.65%) valid choice observations across all participants.

div.head: Choice preference
div.p: We applied a simple Bayesian logistic model (with the rstanarm package in R) that regressed the choices on (a) the task domain (gain vs. loss), (b) probability levels, (c) frame of zero outcome (win ¥0 vs. lose ¥0 vs. hidden ¥0), and (d) their interactions (see Supplemental Material Table S2 for the regression coefficients). Following best practices in using Bayesian statistics (van de Schoot et al., 2021), we report the means of the posterior predictive distribution of the likelihood of choosing risky options (M; i.e., the model predicted risky preference) and the corresponding highest density interval (HDI). Because the model parameter was estimated in a Bayesian fashion, the effects were regarded as significant if the 95% parameter HDI excluded 0 and as a trend if the 90% HDI excluded 0. For the simple-effect analyses, we report the difference in the means of the posterior predictive distribution of the likelihood of choosing a risky option among conditions (Mdiff). To better explore how the mutablezero effect plays a role in choice preference at different probability levels, we selected representative probability levels: 25% for the small probability level, 50% for the medium probability level, and 75% for the high probability level in simple-effect analyses.

We found that zero outcome frames in general affected individuals' risk preferences ( Fig. 2A and Supplemental Material Table S3), and this effect was affected by task domain and probability (Fig. 2B).

Specifically, in the gain domain, with choice preference in the "hidden ¥0" condition as the baseline, participants tended to be less likely to choose for risky options when presented with "win ¥0" compared to "hidden ¥0" (Fig. 2C). Also, participants were more inclined to choose risky options in the "lose ¥0" condition compared to the "win ¥0" condition (see Table S3, Mdiff (gain(Win ¥0-Lose ¥0)) = -0.08, -0.11, -0.14 1 ; all HDIs excluded 0). However, the mutable-zero effect caused by the "win ¥0" condition mainly performed in the small and medium probability intervals (See Table S3, Mdiff (gain(Win ¥0-Hidden ¥0)) = -0.04, -0.03, -0.02; HDIs excluded 0 in the 25% and 50% probability levels but included 0 in the 75% probability level). Conversely, in the "lose ¥0" condition, participants were more likely to choose risky options compared to the "hidden ¥0" condition in three probability levels (see Table S3, Mdiff (gain(Lose ¥0 Hidden ¥0)) = 0.04, 0.08, 0.12, all HDIs excluded 0).

As for the loss domain, participants were also more prone to choose risky options in the "lose ¥0" condition compared to the "win ¥0" condition, while only under the small and medium probability levels (see Table S3, Mdiff (loss(Win ¥0-Lose ¥0)) = -0.11, -0.05, 0.00; HDIs excluded 0 in the 25% and 50% probability levels but included 0 in the 75% probability level). Similarly, compared to the "hidden ¥0" condition, participants were less likely to opt for risky options when presented with the "win ¥0" condition, and such an effect was only present on probabilities that were less than 50% (see Table S3 and Fig. 2C, Mdiff (loss(Win ¥0-Hidden ¥0)) = -0.09, -0.03, 0.02; HDIs excluded 0 in the 25% and 50% probability levels but included 0 in the 75% probability level). In the "lose ¥0" condition, participants were likely to choose risky options compared to the "hidden ¥0" condition in three probability levels, but it was not significant (see Table S3 and Fig. 2C, Mdiff (loss(Lose ¥0 -Hidden ¥0)) = 0.02, 0.02, 0.02; all HDIs included 0).

Taken together, at the behavioral level, we replicated and, more importantly, extended the mutablezero effect with a wide and varying risk levels, with choice preference varied across domains and probabilities in risky choices. Specifically, describing zero outcomes with a losing frame makes the choice more preferable than that with a winning frame: If zero outcomes were described as "win ¥0", people would be more risk-aversive, but when zero outcomes are described as "lose ¥0", people would be more risk-seeking. However, effects related to "win ¥0" mainly applied to small to medium probability levels (25%-57%) in the gain domain and to small probability levels (smaller than 50%) in the loss domain. Effects related to "lose ¥0" applied to a relatively large range of probability levels (larger than 25%) in the gain domain and such effect became stronger as the probability level increased, whereas "lose ¥0" had little impact on choice preferences in the loss domain.

div.head: Attention pattern
div.p: To measure how attention changed across the zero outcome frames, we set eight non-overlapping, identically sized (160 × 110 pixels) rectangular regions of interest (ROIs), each covering one choice attribute (see Fig. 1, top). That is, the probability and outcome attributes of the non-zero outcomes of the risky and certain options and the corresponding probability and outcome attributes of the zero outcomes. We recorded the dwell time of the eye-tracking data on all the ROIs per trial, which measured the sum of the durations of the fixations to reflect the amount of attention to each ROI (Kessels & Ruite, 2012).

We also used a rstanarm package to perform a Bayesian regression analysis that regressed the dwell time of ROIs onto (a) task domain (gain vs. loss), (b) levels probability, (c) zero outcome frame (win ¥0 vs. lose ¥0 vs. hidden ¥0), (d) ROIs of option level (risky vs. certain), (e) ROIs of outcome level (zero vs. non-zero), and (f) their interaction (see Supplemental Material Table S4 for the regression coefficients). Similar to the analysis of choice preference, we reported the means of the posterior predictive distribution of the dwell time (M; i.e., the model predicted dwell time) and the 95% and 90% highest density interval (HDI). We report the difference in the mean of the posterior predictive distribution of dwell time (Mdiff) for simple effect analyses among conditions. Furthermore, we selected 25% for the small probability level, 50% for the medium probability level, and 75% for the high probability level to compare the posterior predictive distribution of dwell time between the three zero outcome frames based on the option and outcome levels to analyze the attention pattern of the mutablezero effect. At the option level, we took the different values of the dwell time between risky options (see Fig. 1, top, ROIs with dotted rectangles) and certain options (see Fig. 1, top, ROIs with solid rectangles) as the dependent variable and compared how different zero outcome frames affect the attention pattern between options. Positive different values indicated more attentional bias for risky options, whereas negative values indicated attentional bias for certain options. At the outcome level, we took the dwell time on zero outcomes (see Fig. 1, top, ROIs with red rectangles) and non-zero outcomes (see Fig. 1, top, ROIs with blue rectangles) and their difference as the dependent variable to analyze whether presenting zero outcomes would influence the attention pattern within options.

div.head: Option level
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2C and Supplemental Material Table S5, presenting zero all HDIs excluded 0), leading to an attentional bias for the risky option. These results indicate that presenting zero outcomes can promote individuals' attentional biases towards risky options.

Together, the results of eye-movement data analysis showed that though the co-existing zero outcome in risky option is considered "null" in its value, it attracted attention to itself and altered the attention allocation between non-zero outcomes and zero outcomes. In addition, presenting zero in both gain and loss frames prompted individuals' attentional biases towards risky options.

div.head: Outcome level
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2D and Supplemental Material Table S6, participants' dwell time on zero outcomes and non-zero outcomes were longer in the "win ¥0" condition than that in the "lose ¥0" condition, and these differences were significant at multiple probability levels (for zero outcomes, Mdiff (gain(Win ¥0-Lose ¥0)) = 25.85, 21.03, 15.90; Mdiff (loss(Win ¥0-Lose ¥0))=45.99, 32.66, 19.01; HDIs excluded 0 in the 25% and 50% probability levels in the gain and loss domains; for non-zero outcomes, Mdiff (gain(Win ¥0 -Lose ¥0)) = 48.22, 47.16, 46.10; HDIs excluded 0 in the 50% probability level in the gain domain; Mdiff (loss(Win ¥0-Lose ¥0)) = 79.55, 49.84, 19.97; HDIs excluded 0 in 25% and 50% probability levels in the loss domain). Additionally, participants' dwell time increased on zero outcomes both in the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions compared to that in the "hidden ¥0" condition under both domains (see Fig. 2D and Table A6, Mdiff In summary, presenting zero outcomes attracts individuals' attention and decreases their attention towards non-zero outcomes. Moreover, participants allocate more attention to non-zero outcomes compared to zero outcomes when zero outcomes are described as "win ¥0" rather than "lose ¥0". the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions, between the "win ¥0" and the "hidden ¥0" conditions, and between the "lose ¥0" and "hidden ¥0" conditions in the gain (left) and loss (right) domains. (C) The difference of predicted dwell time of ROIS at option level. At option level, the dependent variable is the predicted dwell time difference between risky and certain options. Each line represents the difference of predicted dwell time at option level between the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions, between the "win ¥0" and the "hidden ¥0" conditions, and between the "lose ¥0" and "hidden ¥0" conditions across probabilities in the gain (left) and loss (right) domains. (D) The difference of predicted dwell time of ROIS at outcome level. At outcome level, the dependent variable is the predicted dwell time of none-zero and zero outcomes. Each line represents the difference of predicted dwell time of non-zero outcomes (top) and zero outcomes (bottom) between the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions, between the "win ¥0" and the "hidden ¥0" conditions, and between the "lose ¥0" and "hidden ¥0" conditions across probabilities in the gain (left) and loss (right) domains. All shaded areas in B, C and D indicate the 95% highest density interval (HDI).

div.head: Computational modeling
div.p: To identify the underlying cognitive processes, we modeled behavioral data using aDDM combined with CPT (Fig. 3). The canonical DDM defines decision-making as a noisy, bounded evidence-integration process; a response is generated only if the accumulated evidence reaches or surpasses a particular criterion (Forstmann et al., 2016;Ratcliff & McKoon, 2008). The canonical DDM decomposes the response time (RT) and choice data into four cognitively meaningful parameters: the drift rate ( ) , which depicts the speed of evidence integration; the boundary parameter ( ) , which determines the evidence required for making decisions; the initial bias ( ) of evidence integration; and the non-decision time ( 0 ), which governs visual encoding and motor time. The aDDM extends this canonical DDM by incorporating the influence of attention into evidence accumulation. Specifically, the aDDM assumes that evidence integration is biased towards the option that is allocated more attention.

By combining gaze data (which provide a proxy for attention) with choice data, the aDDM can provide insights into how attention impacts the evidence accumulation process (Pleskac et al., 2022). Difference of the likelihood of choosing risky options between the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions, between the "win ¥0" and the "hidden ¥0" conditions, and between the "lose ¥0" and "hidden ¥0" conditions across probabilities in the gain (left) and loss (right) domains.

We fitted two variants of aDDM, a multiplicative aDDM and an additive aDDM, to the behavioral data. We model risky choices as the upper boundary and certain choices as the lower boundary in aDDM (Rieskamp 2008;Sheng et al. 2020;Zhao et al. 2020). This approach allowed us to treat the initial bias parameter ( ) as a predisposing attitude that indicates intuition (Chen & Krajbich, 2018;Desai & Krajbich, 2021). Before model fitting, we excluded trials whose RT was either shorter than 0.4s or longer than 8s to ensure that the estimated parameters were reliable (Peters & D'Esposito, 2020).

The multiplicative aDDM assumed that, at each time point , the drift rate was computed as follows: where and denote the utilities of the risky and certain options, respectively. is the white noise in evidence accumulation. (0 < < 1) is the multiplicative attentional bias parameters, where a value smaller than 1 indicates that the utility of the unattended attribute is discounted. 1 is the non-zero outcome attentional bias parameter, whereas 2 is for the zero outcome.

The additive aDDM assumed that, at each time point , the drift rate was computed as follows: 2)where is the additive attentional bias parameter. is non-negative, indicating facilitated evidence accumulation process for towards the attended attribute. 1 is the attentional bias for non-zero outcomes,
whereas 2 corresponds to zero outcomes. is a scalling parameter that converts utility differences to drift rages.

In addition, to examine the potential differing attentional biases between risky and sure options, we fitted a variant of additive aDDM, which incorporated separate attentional bias parameters for each option type (risky and certain). However, this more complex model did not outperform the simpler ones.
Detailed information on the LOOIC comparisons can be found in Supplemental Material Table S7.
To bridge aDDM with utility computations (i.e., and ), we employed the wellestablished CPT (Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). In the CPT, each option's utility ( ) is defined as follows:

In Equation 3, ( ) is the value function (further specified in Equation 4) and ( ) is the probability weighting function (further specified in Equation 5). We opted the Prelec one-parameter function for the probability weight function, as previous studies revealed that a single parameter was sufficient for accurately modeling the aggregate choice data (Broomell & Bhatia, 2014;Gonzalez & Wu, 1999;Prelec, 1998;Stott, 2006). ( ) and ( ) are defined as follows:
where α modulates the concavity/convexity degree, and γ is shape parameter of probability function.

Together, these two parameters quantify whether participants were risk-seeking or risk-aversive. For completeness, we also fitted candidate models with alternative ways of utility computation (the CPT model, expected utility model, and CPT model without the value function) with also the one-parameter probability weight weighting function (Nilsson et al., 2011;Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). None of them outperformed the presented model above (Supplemental Material Table S8 and Table S9 for model comparison).

To better understand the relationship between framing effect and mutable-zero effect, we additionally fitted models which allow the value function shape parameter , probability function shape parameter , and drift rate scaling parameter to be varied based on the gain and loss domain. This model is referred to as the "framing effect model." We modeled these three parameters with a linear function as follows:

To make sure the parameter values were located in the proper range, the output of the and parameters was transformed through the sigmoid function ( ( ) = 1/(1 + − ) ) whereas the parameter transformed using the softplus function ( ( ) = (1 + ) ) (Goodfellow et al., 2016;Luce, 1986). Overall, we observed no differences among these parameters in either the gain or the loss domain. Detailed results of this "framing effect model" can be found in Supplemental Material Fig. S1 and Supplemental Material Table S10.

div.head: Model estimation and model comparison
div.p: All models were fitted using hierarchical Bayesian analysis (HBA) in the STAN probabilistic language (Ahn et al., 2017;Carpenter et al., 2017;Zhang & Gläscher, 2020). The HBA approximates the parameter posterior by utilizing the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC; also see Supplemental

Material B for details). We used the leave-one-out information criterion (LOOIC) to compare the models, approximating the expected log-pointwise predictive density (ELPD) through Pareto-smoothed importance sampling (PSIS) (Vehtari et al., 2017). Consistent with other information criteria such as the Akaike information criterion (AIC), a lower LOOIC indicates better model performance after controlling for model complexity (Burnham & Anderson, 2004).

Model comparison results showed that the additive aDDM performed better in all three zero outcome frames (See Supplemental Material Table S11). After identifying the best computational model, we performed posterior predictive checks (Palminteri et al., 2017;, as shown in Fig. 3B and C. Our computational model simulations overall aligned with the results of a logistic regression analysis of choice preferences (cf. Fig. 2). Overall, our model encapsulated these behavioral nuances, showing a robust performance in mirroring the observed patterns in decision-making under various conditions.

div.head: Parameter estimates
div.p: We next compared the best-model group-level parameter posterior distributions for all the three zero outcome frames. Although participants' risk preference differed among three zero outcome frames (cf. Fig. 2), parameter comparison showed no differences for the CPT value function parameter during utility computation (Fig. 4A. Strikingly, however, we identified significant differences in aDDM parameters among different zero outcome frames. First, boundary parameters in the "lose ¥0" and "win ¥0" conditions were greater than in the "hidden ¥0" condition, which suggests participants were more cautious and prudent when making decisions in the "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" conditions (see Fig. 4F. . Second, we found that the starting point parameter in the "lose ¥0" condition was larger than that in the "win ¥0" condition (see Fig. 4C.

¥0 − ¥0 = 0.180, 95% HDI = [0.005, 0.359]). This suggested that participants exhibited a stronger predisposition bias towards the risky option in "lose ¥0" compared to "win ¥0", even prior trials were initiated.

Importantly, regarding the attentional bias parameter in the aDDM, the zero outcome attentional bias differed in the "lose ¥0" and "win ¥0" conditions (see Fig. 4E. 2 ¥0 − 2 ¥0 = 0.339, 95% HDI = [0.063, 0.611]). However, participants did not show any difference in the non-zero outcome (see Together, these results indicate that in the "lose ¥0" condition, even when individuals were focused on the zero outcome, they still exhibited a significant attentional bias towards that option, whose utility computation was intact among conditions.

To explore the relationship between attentional biases in zero and non-zero outcomes, we additionally tested the difference between the two attentional bias parameters within each same zero frame. In the "lose ¥0" and "hidden ¥0", there was no effect between the two parameters ("lose ¥0":

1 − 2 = 0.178, 95% HDI = [-0.103, 0.459]; "hidden ¥0": 1 − 2 = 0.230, 95% HDI = [-0.209, 0.639]), while in the "win ¥0" condition, the attentional bias in the non-zero outcome attribute was larger than the zero outcome attribute ( 1 − 2 =0.420, 95% HDI = [0.214, 0.628]).

Finally, we performed a Bayesian regression analysis on the aggregate data from all three zero outcome frames using the Python package Bambi (Capretto et al., 2022) to investigate the relationship between the probability of choosing risky options and parameters derived from the computational modeling analysis. These parameters include CPT value scaling ( ), CPT probability weighting ( ), aDDM drift rate scaling parameter ( ), aDDM starting point parameter ( ), aDDM attentional bias parameter for the non-zero outcome ( 1 ), and the difference in aDDM attentional bias parameters between the non-zero and zero outcome ( 1 − 2 ) (see Fig. 4I). We did not include the aDDM boundary separation parameter because it only affected influences the choice consistency and RT rather than the choice per se.

Results revealed no significant link between the choice data either both CPT parameters ( = . Notably, the attentional bias parameter for non-zero outcomes (β1) was generally larger than that for zero outcomes (β2), as observed in 76 of 110 participants. A negative regression coefficient ( 1 − 2 ) implies that an increased attentional effect difference towards non-zero outcomes correlate with a reduced chance of participants choosing the 4), indicate that the mutable-zero effect arises from the starting point and attentional bias parameters, rather than from the prospect theory parameters.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The mutable-zero effect explores how presenting zero outcomes as "winning $0" or "losing $0" can asymmetrically influence subsequent choice preferences in economic choices. To date, however, little is known about whether mutable-zero effect pertains to risky decision-making and what cognitive mechanisms underlie it. Our study addressed this fundamental question by employing a combined behavioral, eye-tracking, and computational modeling approach to comprehensively examine the mutable-zero effect across varied probability levels and explored the attentional process underlying it during risky economic choices. Our findings unearthed intriguing insights of the mutable-zero effect, shedding light on its impact on decision-making across varied probability levels.

Behaviorally, framing zero outcomes as "lose $0" made gambling more preferable than framing them as "win $0." "Winning $0" prompted individuals to become more risk-aversive, predominantly impacting risky options with small to medium probability levels in both gain and loss domains.
Conversely, "losing $0" led individuals to be more risk-seeking, primarily impacting the gain domain.

Moreover, participants generally showed risk-aversive tendencies across the three zero outcome frame conditions in the gain domain. As probability levels became larger, participants became more riskaversive in the hidden zero and "win ¥0" conditions; however, participants' choice preferences remained relatively unchanged in the "lose ¥0" condition, suggesting a reduction in risk-aversive tendency. In the loss domain, participants displayed heightened risk-seeking tendencies with increasing probability levels in both explicit and hidden zero conditions. However, in the "win ¥0" condition, there was a downward trend in participants' risk-seeking tendencies at lower to medium probability levels.

Therefore, it seems that the mutable-zero effect does not exacerbate individuals' tendencies towards risk-seeking or risk-aversive behavior. Rather, presenting zero outcome steers behavior towards normal in situations where individuals exhibit decision biases (Kühberger & Tanner, 2010;Zhou et al., 2019Zhou et al., , 2021).

By combining eye-tracking and computational modeling, our results provide novel attentional explanations for mutable-zero effect in economic choices. As showed in Fig. 2B, our model can capture the combined influence of probability and framing on the zero effect, a relationship that previous models have not addressed. The analysis of eye-movement patterns revealed a noticeable impact of zero outcomes on attention allocation, leading to a bias towards risky options. This finding is consistent with previous research highlighting the influence of explicitly presenting zero outcomes in drawing more attention to the overall option (Dang et al., 2021;Radu et al., 2011;Zhou et al., 2019). In addition, computational modeling, integrating aDDM and CPT, quantified the attentional mechanisms behind the mutable-zero effect, showing that "win ¥0" and "lose ¥0" led to asymmetric attentional biases influencing choice preferences. Specifically, "win ¥0" evoked a stronger attentional bias towards nonzero outcomes compared to zero outcomes. Since "win ¥0" is considered a "bad zero" due to the negative perception of receiving nothing, individuals may be more concern about whether risky options actually deliver a return. For the "lose ¥0", the attentional bias toward zero outcomes and the starting point parameter were significantly larger than "win ¥0", indicating a bias towards zero outcomes at the pre-decision stage. The starting point parameter, which is regarded as more reflective of the automatic process (Zhao et al., 2019), has previously been linked to the arousal system (de Gee et al., 2020;Sheng et al., 2020). Thus, the prior bias towards risky options in the "lose ¥0" condition may stem from the positive emotions evoked by the frame of zero, influencing early sensory processing.

For parameters of the CPT component, we found no difference in parameters which represent individuals' outcome and probability sensitivity (Pachur et al., 2018), across all three zero outcome frames. This result indicates limited impact of zero outcomes on decision bias related to probability distortion in CPT (Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). However, we identified variations in attentional bias for zero outcomes, which is in line with research by Zilker et al. on probability distortion in CPT and attention allocation (Pachur et al., 2018;Zilker, 2022;Zilker & Pachur, 2022;Zilker & Pachur, 2023).
Together, these findings suggest that effects initially attributed to CPT may be explained by attentional mechanisms.

We note a few caveats of the present study. The additive aDDM outperformed the multiplicative aDDM in all three zero outcome frames, suggesting that attention may have a simple and independent additive influence on option selection. However, this does not rule out the possibility of an interaction between option values and attention, as proposed by the multiplicative model. In the experiment design, we did not vary the option value and did not examine the assumption by the multiplicative model that attention to higher value options exerts a greater effect on decision-making (Smith & Krajbich, 2019).

Future research could explore this by varying option values to test the model's assumption that attention to higher value options has a greater impact on decision-making. Additionally, our experiment used choice pairs with approximately equal expected values (EVs), and future work could benefit from incorporating a wider range of EV magnitudes to investigate potential alterations in the mutable-zero effect. Moreover, future studies could consider employing a paradigm with multiple risky options to examine how multiple zero outcomes may influence choice preferences.

In conclusion, our study not only deepened the understanding of the mutable-zero effect and its implications for decision-making but also challenged traditional expected utility-based models of economic choices. By highlighting the role of attentional processes in shaping decision preferences, our findings contribute to the broader theoretical landscape of decision-making research, emphasizing the need to consider attention as a factor in decision-making models. These insights have theoretical significance in enriching our understanding of the cognitive mechanisms and boundary conditions of the mutable-zero effect, and broaden the explanatory scope of this effect across different probability levels. Furthermore, our study has practical implications for influencing economic choices. For instance, to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060, the Chinese government has been actively promoting low-carbon behaviors among citizens, such as incentivizing people to buy electric vehicles through purchase tax breaks on new energy vehicles (The State Council of the People's Republic of China, 2023). By revealing the potential impact of presenting different zero outcomes on individuals' economic decisionmaking, this study offers important insights into leveraging the mutable-zero effect as a tool to influence behavior.

div.head: Constraints on Generality
div.p: As this study focused primarily on a sample of young adults, all of whom were undergraduate students, there are inherent constraints on the generalizability of the results to broader populations and contexts. For example, the findings may not extend to older adults or individuals with cognitive impairments, whose decision-making processes might differ significantly. Additionally, while the exclusion criteria ensured data quality by removing extreme outliers, these same criteria (e.g., response times beyond three standard deviations or exceeding 20,000ms) may limit applicability to real-world settings where time pressure and distractions are more varied. Furthermore, the study focused on a specific task within a controlled environment, which may not fully capture the complexities of decisionmaking in everyday life.

figure.figDesc: Experimental design (Top) and procedure (Bottom). Experimental trial in the "win ¥0" (A and D, in light purple), "lose ¥0" (B and E, in light orange), and "hidden ¥0" (C and F, in light blue) between-subject conditions, and gain domain (A, B and C) and loss domain (D, E and F) in the within-subject conditions. Rectangles around the choice contents represent the regions of interest (ROIs) and were not visible to participants. Dotted rectangles = risky options;

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: (A) Proportion of choosing risky options. Violin plot for percentage of risky choices in three zero outcome framings in the gain (left) and loss (right) domains. Box plots indicate the interquartile range and medians are indicated by a white horizontal line. (B) The posterior predictive likelihood of choosing risky option. Top: the posterior predictive likelihood of choosing risky options across probabilities for three zero outcome framings in the gain domain (left) and in the loss domain (right). Bottom: the difference of predictive likelihood of choosing risky options between

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: (A) Conceptual illustration of computational modeling. Participants choices (risky vs. certain) are modeled by combining attentional drift diffusion modeling (aDDM) with cumulative prospect theory (CPT). Importantly, the drift rate is modulated (denoted as "f" for generic modulation depending on the model type) by both the choice utility (computed with CPT for risky and certain options) and the attention toward choice options (net attention among the three options: risky option with non-zero outcome, risky option with zero outcome, certain option).(B) Model validation with posterior predictive check (PPC) for likelihood of choosing risky option. For three zero outcome frames, the posterior predictive likelihood of choosing risky options across probabilities in the gain (left) and loss domain (right). (C) Model validation with posterior predictive check (PPC) for difference of likelihood of choosing risky option.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Posterior parameter distributions for the aDDM and standardized regression coefficients of model parameters, specifically for three prospect theory parameters (α (plot A), γ (plot B) and (plot H)), starting point parameter z (plot C), attentional bias parameters ( 1 (plot D), 2 (plot E)), boundary parameter (plot F), nondecision time parameter 0 (plot G), and parameter. Each plot uses different colors to distinguish between the three outcome conditions (i.e., win, lose, and hidden). For standardized regression coefficients of model parameters (plot I), the x-axis lists the parameters incorporated into the regression models, including the three prospect theory parameters( , and ), starting point parameter ( ) and two attentional bias parameters ( and − 2 ). Note that all predictors have been standardized making the regression coefficients directly comparable.
